ygData.subject: Re: HyperNEAT: Creating Neural Networks with CPPNs

Joe, I may not be fully understanding your point, so I wanted to ask 
for c=
larification.  My point was only that CPPNs can abstract away 
the temporal=
 unfolding and local interaction that are usually 
associated with developm=
ent.  You are saying something that does not 
seem in opposition to this po=
int, but I may be misunderstanding.  It 
seems you are saying that "pattern=
 recognition" gives a powerful 
capability to traditional developmental sys=
tems in terms of being 
able to target mutations to specific areas.  I woul=
d not disagree 
with that point.

However, what I would say, which may simp=
ly be consistent with what 
you are saying, is that CPPNs abstract away the=
 need for there to be 
such pattern recognition in order to get either glob=
al or local 
targeted mutations.  I still submit that the targeted mutation=
s to 
which you are referring ultimately hinge on "where am I?"  Because 
h=
ow did the liver cell ultimately figure out it was a liver cell?  
It's bec=
ause of its neighbors, and so forth.  It's all context-
dependent.

On the =
other hand, in the CPPN, the liver is a local coordinate 
frame (i.e. some =
internal node) that is built upon (i.e. a function 
of) other coordinate fr=
ames.  So in effect the same thing is going 
on, just in a different way.  =
But ultimately it "knows" it is a 
liver cell in either case.  In the CPPN =
this knowledge is simply 
encapsulated as the node in the CPPN itself where=
 the coordinate 
frame is represented.  A mutation thereabout will effect o=
nly those 
cells within that coordinate frame.  So you get targeted mutatio=
ns 
just as well without "pattern recognition."

I think what I'm saying is=
 consistent with the results that you cite 
from your paper since I fully b=
elieve that IF you are using a 
traditional developmental encoding, "patter=
n recognition" indeed 
carries the benefits you cite.  So I expect you coul=
d demonstrate it 
experimentally. 

I think this is a great discussion to h=
ave.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrot=
e:
>
> Hi Ken,
> 
> I have one (small) point of clarification to add to you=
r 
exposition  
> here:
> 
> > "genes essentially 'pattern recognize' certa=
in areas in the
> > organism"
> >
> > That is absolutely correct for biolog=
ical organisms, and for
> > iterated developmental systems in general.  How=
ever, the deep
> > question is *why* should they need to "pattern recognize=
" certain
> > areas?
> >
> > And the answer is because they need to know wh=
ere they are.  In
> > effect, in the physical universe, there is no intrins=
ic 
coordinate
> > system that cells can query to ask their location.  Thus=
, they 
must
> > develop elaborate and ad hoc ways of communicating to each=
 
other, as
> > a group, where everyone is.  I send my neighbor signals, my=
 
neighbor
> > sends me signals back, and we negotiate our roles.
> >
> > M=
y undoubtedly controversial contention is that the 
question "where
> > am =
I?" is the ONLY reason that such negotation is necessary.  If 
you
> > didn=
't have to ask that question, then you would not need to 
talk to
> > your =
neighbors in order to determine your role.  Rather, you 
could
> > just com=
pute your role as a function of your known
> > coordinate/position in the w=
orld.
> 
> Your answer to "why we need to pattern recognize" is a little  
=
> incomplete. Basically you've only answered this from the cell's  
> persp=
ective. Lets consider "pattern recognize" from the 
perspective  
> of the =
developmental program instead of the cell. Then the main  
> question is "h=
ow do I select a bunch of cells that match some  
> property?" That is, I w=
ant to select some contiguous region, 
e.g.,  
> "toe cells" or "heart cell=
s" or maybe I want to select something 
more  
> developmentally useful, e.=
g. "epithelial cells" or "cells in some  
> stripe pattern along the HOX ax=
is."
> 
> Why is this useful? Because then we can make mutations that 
affe=
ct  
> these areas and no others, i.e. mutation selectivity that is 
define=
d  
> for some (hopefully) useful phenotypic axes of variation. A lot 
of  =

> useful things fall out naturally from this idea, like modularity 
or  
>=
 evolvability (this is where I cite my GECCO 2007 paper, which is 
not  
> =
yet on the web). In CPPN terms it would be like being able to 
select,  
> =
say, all the black stripes in a sine grating, but not the white 
ones.  
> =
If I'm not mistaken, CPPNs support this idea of regional 
selection  
> ver=
y nicely, so I'm not sure why you don't mention it here.
> 
> Anyway, I tot=
ally agree that doing away with the "negotiation" 
step  
> required for de=
velopmental systems using purely local interactions 
is  
> a useful optimi=
zation, but I wouldn't be so quick to say that 
being  
> able to "pattern =
recognize" certain areas serves the sole purpose 
of  
> localization with =
respect to only the global coordinate system.
> 
> I'll go into this issue =
in more detail in my talk at GECCO, but I  
> think its very important, and=
 our empirical results seem to back 
it  
> up quite strongly.
> 
> -- Joe
=
> 
> http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~joeraii
